current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
To amend the Public Health Service Act to reauthorize
		  programs under part A of title XI of such Act.

committee-name.#text:
Committee on Health, Education, Labor,
			 and Pensions

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
Newborn Screening Saves Lives
			 Reauthorization Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the

The table of
			 contents of this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.

Sec. 2. Improved newborn and child screening and follow-up for
				heritable disorders.

Sec. 3. Evaluating the effectiveness of newborn and child
				screening and follow-up programs.

Sec. 4. Advisory committee on heritable disorders in newborns
				and children.

Sec. 5. Clearinghouse of Newborn Screening
				Information.

Sec. 7. Interagency Coordinating Committee on Newborn and Child
				Screening.

Sec. 8. National contingency plan for newborn
				screening.

			 Public Health Service Act

header.#text:
Evaluating the
			 effectiveness of newborn and child screening and follow-up
			 programs

text.#text: in the section heading, by inserting

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
,
			 by striking the period at the end and inserting a semicolon; and

text.#text:
by adding at the
			 end the following:

the costs and
				effectiveness of newborn screening, evaluation and intervention programs, and
				surveillance systems conducted by State-based programs in order to answer
				issues of importance to State and national policymakers;

the effectiveness
				of newborn screening follow-up and intervention programs through the assessment
				of the health and development of children at school age and as young
				adults;

the coordination
				of surveillance activities, including—

standardized data
				collection and reporting; and

the facilitation
				of quality improvement in treatment and disease management based on gaps in
				services or care identified by longitudinal tracking systems; and

the utilization of data from longitudinal
				tracking systems to support the development and evaluation of evidence-based
				guidelines for diagnosis, treatment, and disease
				management.
